{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3160856,"name":"Erdem Tellioglu","username":"Erdemtel1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erdemtel1/{size}/188063_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T15:40:10.767Z","cooked":"

Basically, due to our gripper and elevator mechanism being on the front of the robot, the center of mass is also there and we need to move it as close as possible to middle of the robot. I have shared the photo of our robot. What do you think we should do other than adding extra weights to the back of the robot ?

image1170×1998 201 KB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T15:40:10.767Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":93,"reads":254,"readers_count":253,"score":515.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":429569,"topic_slug":"center-of-mass-adjustment","display_username":"Erdem Tellioglu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/c/6/c6a3168c197343c41188687d5daddfbd186816d2.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55700,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/center-of-mass-adjustment/429569/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3160869,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T15:46:00.956Z","cooked":"

What’s already at the back of the robot? Battery? Compressor?

If those two aren’t at the back already, they should be. After that, you’re pretty much stuck with adding weights.

Yes they are already at the back, thanks we will add some weights then.

We had a similar issue, solved it by bolting a ~10lb. block of steel to our chassis.

We’ve currently got 25 lbs of metal weights in the front of our robot for counter weight, it’s the simplest solution if you have the overhead to do it.

Are your diagonals enclosed tubes? What does the bottom end look like? You might consider dumping some ball bearings or buckshot into them. make sure the tube is entirely sealed so they don’t roll out if you tip. Alternatively, find some sealed SCUBA weights and zip-tie them around the bottoms of the diagonals. Be careful of Rule R203(k).

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-03-09T16:46:00.245Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":27,"reads":160,"readers_count":159,"score":167.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":429569,"topic_slug":"center-of-mass-adjustment","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/center-of-mass-adjustment/429569/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3160983,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-09T17:15:27.855Z","cooked":"

c6a3168c197343c41188687d5daddfbd186816d2_2_584x1000~2584×1000 74.8 KB

Others have talked about adding or shifting mass. Here are some more ideas (with smaller returns than just added 10lbs of steel to the back of the bot or relocating the battery)

Green area, aluminum fasteners and thin wall tube where you can get away with it if it isn’t already. Shift the grabber cylinder back closer to the bot and extend the road with aluminum all thread and aluminum coupling nuts. (This will help the arm angle cylinder performance too)

Red area: 2 force member, you may be able to get away with aluminum angle here instead (if not completely remove) due to struts in the back.

Yellow area: reduce mass, looks like you are driving with 2 chances. This matters in wide elevators, bit narrow ones so much.

Finally, don’t drive across the field with the arm angled out, lower it back into robot.

Not sure you have the room, but it is possible to run a WCD with the motors direct driving the rear wheels rather than the center wheels.
